title: 108_hr3424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Violence Courts Assistance Act". The Congress finds that domestic violence is a significant issue in the United States, with one-third of women experiencing abuse. This results in substantial costs to the nation and has led to the establishment of specialized domestic violence courts in various states to address the issue effectively. Specialized domestic violence courts focus on reducing backlog and increasing conviction rates for domestic violence cases, especially with repeat offenders. Establishment of domestic violence court systems using grants to combat violence against women. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include the establishment and maintenance of court systems dedicated to domestic violence cases as a purpose for grants to combat violence against women. This includes providing resources such as prosecutors, court personnel, interpretation, and translation services. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include grants for specialized court systems dedicated to domestic violence cases. This includes funding for interpretation and translation services, technical assistance, training for legal professionals, technological improvements, data collection, and court facility enhancements. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include grants for specialized court systems dedicated to domestic violence cases, including juvenile courts and specialized domestic violence courts. The Attorney General is required to submit a report to Congress on the implementation and effectiveness of these amendments, including the impact on reducing domestic violence rates and expediting judicial review in domestic violence cases. Additionally, amendments are made to the State Justice Institute Act of 1984 to further support these specialized court systems. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include grants for specialized court systems dedicated to domestic violence cases. This includes implementing and evaluating court-based approaches such as domestic violence courts, integrated case management systems, collaborations among various agencies, and providing technical assistance to improve the criminal justice system's response to domestic violence. Authorization of Appropriations: $1,500,000 for each fiscal year 2005 through 2008 is authorized to carry out specialized court systems for domestic violence cases.
